content.description: A good route with good movement. There is a short reachy crux section about halfway up just before you pull over a small lip to the "Thank God no hands rest ledge". First bolt is pretty high so if you're not solid in the grade bring a stick clip. Good exposure and a great view at the top.
content.location: About 20' left of Show Boat "Horseshoe 8" on legacy wall start is on a small mini arete.

content.description: Head up left side of large stack of boulders to reach first anchor. Reach high to gain second anchor for the top of the rock stack. Small lower roof is below steep slab. Hueco holes start below the upper roof and angling crack, then continue in a sequential fashion, leading into the crux. Traverse a couple steps left to utilize the upper arete. Balance is key. Keep from becoming pumped by resting when possible. Quite a fun line!
content.protection: 6 bolts, 4 perma- draws and mussy hooks.There is a safety bolt lower for you and your belayer that looks like part of beer ledge.
content.location: Route is a line of bolts that continue straight up from the top of the large stack of boulders. Stick clip could be handy for clipping past the lower small roof. Guess it depends on your person ethics.

content.description: Some continued cleaning needed below the second or third bolt and just below the rap anchors, otherwise this line is quite fun. Pockets and exciting movement makes for another good line at Robinson!
content.location: Start just left of Party Boat, on the lower slab, then stay on the left edge of the steep section of rock.

content.description: Easy 4th class climbing gets you up to the 1st bolt then jugs to the second. Now standing, in the base of the dihedral, easy 5th class (5.3 - 5.4) stemming gets you up to the two bolt anchor.
content.location: Two routes left of Party Boat, identity the dihedral and how the start is the same for two different lines. The dihedral is Show Boat and the arete line is called Contrived. Contrived has a separate set of rap anchors.

content.description: If your going to be a Vandal you'll have to do Saturday Detention. 31m if fun. The fun starts right off the ground so make sure you're solid or stickclip the first bolt.    First Crux comes about 45' pulling through the small overhang. Footwork is everything here with little high stepping fun it should be no problem. The climbing is pretty consistent for the rating through the whole route
content.location: The first route to the right of "Vandal" on legacy wall. When you come to Legacy wall find the tall dihedral that is "Horseshoe 8". Left of it you'll find Vandal and Saturday detention. Vandal is the line that finishes to the left of the large cedar tree at the top of the bluff and Saturday Detention finishes on the right of the tree.

content.description: This is a 2 pitch route.  Pitch 1 - Start on the fun lower slab then head up and into the left facing dihedral crack. This section can get pumpy depending on if you like crack climbing. The right hand side pulls on the other side of the column are fantastic. You'll also encounter an undercling that's a lifesaver.  The crux is moving through the crack and back onto the face. Rap anchors allow for easy quick draw retrieval.Pitch 2 - Fairly easy climbing probably 5.6. Protection for the second pitch is 5 bolts and mussy hooks.
content.protection: Pitch 1 - 7 bolts plus mussy hooks. Pitch 2 - 5 bolts plus mussy hooks.
content.location: Right hand side the Legacy Wall, so the first line you come to when approaching, walking south from the steps. You will drop down along the trail, from the Cryptic Wall, coming around the base of the Three Hour Tour ridge buttress. Party boat starts at the base of the slab.
Left of Beer Ledge and Beer Ledge Boulders.

content.description:
One of the first bolted lines on the Legacy Wall. Legacy was first free climbed by Isaiah Vuaght, out of St. Louis, MO, while he was visiting from school, in Columbia, MO. The route follows a steep line up a dark red face, with a continuous crux on the upper half of the climb.

 Head up the easier lower portion of the line to reach the cave ledge. Large slotted pockets and a wide stance get you up and on the upper face. Climb roughly straight up and slightly left then up to the top anchors.

 When it rains it pours down this line, hence the name of the route.
content.location: See the photos provided for orientation. This line heads up the right side of the steep, slightly overhanging, scooped face. The bolts are in the red stained rock, to the right of the lighter white portion of the overhang. The bolts continue up above the obvious furthest right small cave alcove.

content.description: This route starts 10 feet left of Mr Turtle and 15 right of  Special Delivery. Notice the large hole that starts just right of the third bolt and whose top is just below the fourth bolt. The crux on this route occurs in a thin section above this hole.
content.location: Just left of Mr Turtle, look for the large pocket that sit just below a small roof bulge. Bolts follow a line up then angle slightly up left towards anchors.

content.description: Exit Stage Left is a steep slab line with a short section of creative side stepping to gain the upper section. Step up, smearing on the lower slab, then continue through a steeper section, moving left to exit the crux of the route. Continue up the rest of the steep slab to the top anchors.
content.location: Start just right of the large stack of boulders, located below the routes Tennessee Whisky and Beer Ledge. Step up, smearing on the lower slab that is roughly 30 feet left of Legacy Falls.

content.description: Description coming soon, some cleaning required.

Left of the Party Boat crack, this line starts sharing holds with Show Boat then follows the slight arete straight up. Separate bolts protect this line. Separate rap anchors provided also. You can continue on the second pitch but I do not give it many stars until more cleaning has happened.
content.location: Left (south) of the Party Boat crack, this line starts sharing holds with Show Boat, then follow the slight arete straight up.

content.description:
This tall line involves a diversity of different features and climbing techniques. Quite a good find which didn't easily manifest into existence without a quite a bit of hard work and attention to detail by Norm Reed.

 The slightly overhanging face starts with some easier climbing up through the grey rock section to an elongated pocket crack. Layback and look for a high step and then a smear, moving slightly up and left to gain the next rest position. The next 10 meters involves a face climbing sequence, moving up and slightly right then angling up and left towards a ledge at the base of the upper dihedral. The ledge is your next rest position.

 The upper dihedral and face involves a bit of stemming then back to face climbing. To gain the top rap anchors, continue up right then straight up to the anchors.
content.location: This tall face is to the face right of the Legacy Wall area. Roughly 15 meters south (left) of the Beer Ledge boulders.

content.description: Similar start to Tennessee Whisky, but head up and left from the first bolt, on the left side of the large stack of boulders. Crux is mid way up the route and greatly depends on if you are left or right of the bolt path. Finish on slightly easier climbing.
content.location: Start this line on the left side of the Beer Ledge stack of large boulders. Line follows a dark streak of rock, left of Tennessee Whisky.

content.description:
*Note: We are currently cleaning this wall section. Please announce yourself while hiking and be aware of trail signs, posted warnings, and always wear a helmet.Legacy Wall: This long scoop shaped wall section offers a great mix of steep, shaded climbing during the summer, with plenty of winter morning sunlight. On the right, Party Boat, is the first climb, on the far right side of the wall section, which stays bathed by winter sunlight a bit later then other climbs south of the Grand Staircase. This is known as the 3 Hour Tour Buttress. Further left along the wall, Legacy Falls was the first bolted line along this wall section, heading up to a small cave, then following a line right of the lighter white overhanging rock. This route becomes a water fall during a brief heavy rain. A bit further left, The Beer Ledge boulders are a tall stack at the base of the wall that redirects the walking trail down and around. The large stack also is used to gain the first bolts on Beer Ledge (5.9) and Tennessee Whisky (5.11).

Routes range from 35 ft to 100 ft tall and currently provide a wide range of difficulty levels (range from 5.6 to 5.11). Work in progress.

Ratings:

While easier climbs are given a rating number representing the climb to be no harder than the rating represented, routes rated 5.10 and up are given a specific max crux rating. This should help you plan your visit and navigate your way along the bluff while using Mountain Project.

Please provide feedback

using your MP App. Star rating and rate difficulty feedback helps the next visitors use the app.
